docs.text:
Subscribe to changes on a file


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata.readonly


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.photos.readonly


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.readonly




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 files watch ...


Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file in question.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Channel:
  address: string
  expiration: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  params: { string: string }
  payload: boolean
  resource-id: string
  resource-uri: string
  token: string
  type: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    address=clita


The address where notifications are delivered for this channel.






expiration=est


Date and time of notification channel expiration, expressed as a Unix timestamp, in milliseconds. Optional.






id=sit


A UUID or similar unique string that identifies this channel.






kind=ipsum


Identifies this as a notification channel used to watch for changes to a resource. Value: the fixed string 
api#channel
.






params=key=dolore


Additional parameters controlling delivery channel behavior. Optional.


the value will be associated with the given 
key






payload=true


A Boolean value to indicate whether payload is wanted. Optional.






resource-id=ipsum


An opaque ID that identifies the resource being watched on this channel. Stable across different API versions.






resource-uri=sadipscing


A version-specific identifier for the watched resource.






token=ea


An arbitrary string delivered to the target address with each notification delivered over this channel. Optional.






type=dolor


The type of delivery mechanism used for this channel.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.


As this method supports 
media download
, you may specify the 
-p alt=media
 flag to set the output to be an octet stream of the underlying media. In that case, you will not receive JSON output anymore.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will either be a JSON-encoded structure, or the media file you are downloading.
  The 
destination
 may be 
-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

-p
 is followed by one 
or more key-value-pairs, and is called like this 
-p k1=v1 k2=v2

-p
 for completeness.

Whether the user is acknowledging the risk of downloading known malware or other abusive files.








-p update-viewed-date=boolean




Deprecated: Use files.update with modifiedDateBehavior=noChange, updateViewedDate=true and an empty request body.








-p revision-id=string




Specifies the Revision ID that should be downloaded. Ignored unless alt=media is specified.

This parameter is deprecated and has no function.

The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.  As this method supports  media download , you may specify the  -p alt=media  flag to set the output to be an octet stream of the underlying media. In that case, you will not receive JSON output anymore.   -o out  out  specifies the  destination  to which to write the server's result to.
  It will either be a JSON-encoded structure, or the media file you are downloading.
  The  destination  may be  -  to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

Required Scalar Argument

(string)


The ID of the file.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


ParentReference:
  id: string
  is-root: boolean
  kind: string
  parent-link: string
  self-link: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    id=consetetur


The ID of the parent.






is-root=false


Whether or not the parent is the root folder.






kind=ipsum


This is always drive#parentReference.






parent-link=et


A link to the parent.






self-link=invidunt


A link back to this reference.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.

Scopes

.

drive2 --scope 
scope

Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Permission:
  additional-roles: [string]
  auth-key: string
  domain: string
  email-address: string
  etag: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  name: string
  photo-link: string
  role: string
  self-link: string
  type: string
  value: string
  with-link: boolean





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    additional-roles=amet.


Additional roles for this user. Only commenter is currently allowed.


Each invocation of this argument appends the given value to the array.






auth-key=sit


The authkey parameter required for this permission.






domain=dolor


The domain name of the entity this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user, group or domain.






email-address=et


The email address of the user or group this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user or group.






etag=amet


The ETag of the permission.






id=sit


The ID of the user this permission refers to, and identical to the permissionId in the About and Files resources. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified.






kind=vero


This is always drive#permission.






name=nonumy


The name for this permission.






photo-link=accusam


A link to the profile photo, if available.






role=est


The primary role for this user. Allowed values are:  


owner 


reader 


writer










self-link=sit


A link back to this permission.






type=erat


The account type. Allowed values are:  


user 


group 


domain 


anyone










value=vero


The email address or domain name for the entity. This is used during inserts and is not populated in responses. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified.






with-link=false

auth-key=gubergren


The authkey parameter required for this permission.






domain=clita


The domain name of the entity this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user, group or domain.






email-address=et


The email address of the user or group this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user or group.






etag=justo


The ETag of the permission.






id=clita


The ID of the user this permission refers to, and identical to the permissionId in the About and Files resources. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified.






kind=eos


This is always drive#permission.






name=sea


The name for this permission.






photo-link=clita


A link to the profile photo, if available.






role=tempor


The primary role for this user. Allowed values are:  


owner 


reader 


writer










self-link=stet


A link back to this permission.






type=dolor


The account type. Allowed values are:  


user 


group 


domain 


anyone










value=stet


The email address or domain name for the entity. This is used during inserts and is not populated in responses. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified.






with-link=false

.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..

.

...

Overwrites the Realtime API data model associated with this file with the provided JSON data model.


Scopes

.

drive2 --scope 
scope
 realtime update ...


Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID of the file that the Realtime API data model is associated with.








Required Upload Flags


This method supports the upload of data, which 
requires
 all of the following flags to be set:




-u (simple|resumable)


simple
 - Upload media all at once.


resumable
 - Upload media in a resumable fashion.






-f file


Path to file to upload. It must be seekable.








The following flag 
may
 be set: 




-m mime


the mime type, like 'application/octet-stream', which is the default








Optional Method Properties


You may set the following properties to further configure the call. Please note that 
-p
 is followed by one 
or more key-value-pairs, and is called like this 
-p k1=v1 k2=v2
 even though the listing below repeats the

-p
 for completeness.




-p base-revision=string


The revision of the model to diff the uploaded model against. If set, the uploaded model is diffed against the provided revision and those differences are merged with any changes made to the model after the provided revision. If not set, the uploaded model replaces the current model on the server.

Updates a revision. This method supports patch semantics.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 revisions patch ...


Required Scalar Arguments




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file.






revision-id
 
(string)


The ID for the revision.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Revision:
  download-url: string
  etag: string
  export-links: { string: string }
  file-size: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  last-modifying-user:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  last-modifying-user-name: string
  md5-checksum: string
  mime-type: string
  modified-date: string
  original-filename: string
  pinned: boolean
  publish-auto: boolean
  published: boolean
  published-link: string
  published-outside-domain: boolean
  self-link: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    download-url=lorem


Short term download URL for the file. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






etag=dolor


The ETag of the revision.






export-links=key=amet.


Links for exporting Google Docs to specific formats.


the value will be associated with the given 
key






file-size=sed


The size of the revision in bytes. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






id=sea


The ID of the revision.






kind=consetetur


This is always drive#revision.






last-modifying-user    display-name=sea


A plain text displayable name for this user.






email-address=voluptua.


The email address of the user.






is-authenticated-user=false


Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.






kind=sanctus


This is always drive#user.






permission-id=sit


The user
s ID as visible in the permissions collection.








picture    url=sit




A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.








...    last-modifying-user-name=magna




Name of the last user to modify this revision.






md5-checksum=amet.


An MD5 checksum for the content of this revision. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






mime-type=clita


The MIME type of the revision.






modified-date=stet


Last time this revision was modified (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp).






original-filename=sed


The original filename when this revision was created. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






pinned=false


Whether this revision is pinned to prevent automatic purging. This will only be populated and can only be modified on files with content stored in Drive which are not Google Docs. Revisions can also be pinned when they are created through the drive.files.insert/update/copy by using the pinned query parameter.






publish-auto=true


Whether subsequent revisions will be automatically republished. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






published=false


Whether this revision is published. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






published-link=sit


A link to the published revision.






published-outside-domain=false


Whether this revision is published outside the domain. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






self-link=sea


A link back to this revision.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.
  The 
destination

-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

docs.text:
Updates a revision.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 revisions update ...


Required Scalar Arguments




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file.






revision-id
 
(string)


The ID for the revision.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Revision:
  download-url: string
  etag: string
  export-links: { string: string }
  file-size: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  last-modifying-user:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  last-modifying-user-name: string
  md5-checksum: string
  mime-type: string
  modified-date: string
  original-filename: string
  pinned: boolean
  publish-auto: boolean
  published: boolean
  published-link: string
  published-outside-domain: boolean
  self-link: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    download-url=justo


Short term download URL for the file. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






etag=dolore


The ETag of the revision.






export-links=key=at


Links for exporting Google Docs to specific formats.


the value will be associated with the given 
key






file-size=dolor


The size of the revision in bytes. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






id=tempor


The ID of the revision.






kind=ipsum


This is always drive#revision.






last-modifying-user    display-name=est


A plain text displayable name for this user.






email-address=et


The email address of the user.






is-authenticated-user=false


Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.






kind=sed


This is always drive#user.






permission-id=kasd


The user
s ID as visible in the permissions collection.








picture    url=ipsum




A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.








...    last-modifying-user-name=sadipscing




Name of the last user to modify this revision.






md5-checksum=sea


An MD5 checksum for the content of this revision. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






mime-type=eos


The MIME type of the revision.






modified-date=dolor


Last time this revision was modified (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp).






original-filename=lorem


The original filename when this revision was created. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






pinned=false


Whether this revision is pinned to prevent automatic purging. This will only be populated and can only be modified on files with content stored in Drive which are not Google Docs. Revisions can also be pinned when they are created through the drive.files.insert/update/copy by using the pinned query parameter.






publish-auto=false


Whether subsequent revisions will be automatically republished. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






published=true


Whether this revision is published. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






published-link=nonumy


A link to the published revision.






published-outside-domain=true


Whether this revision is published outside the domain. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






self-link=diam


A link back to this revision.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the

The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.

  If unset, it defaults to standard output.
